title: Welcome
text:
This is a companion for the Pharmaverse Examples.
Each chapter title to the left is a link to a slide deck.

These slides are being developed by this club.
Each deck will open in its own tab.
You may want to type “s” at the start of each deck to open the speaker notes.
Join the Data Science Learning Community to participate in the discussion!

We follow the Data Science Learning Community Code of Conduct.

title: Club Meetings
text:
Book club meetings

Volunteer leads discussion of a set of examples

This is the best way to learn the material.

Presentations:

Review of material
Questions you have
Maybe live demo

More info about editing: this github repo.
Recorded, available on the Data Science Learning Community YouTube Channel (DSLC.video).

title: Club Meetings
text:
Pace

Goal: TBD/week
Ok to split overwhelming example sets
Ok to combine short example sets
Meet every week except holidays, etc

Ideally can discuss even if presenter unavailable

title: Club Meetings
text:
Learning objectives (LOs)

Students who study with LOs in mind retain more.
Tips:

Think “After today’s session, you will be able to {LO}”.
Very roughly 1 per heading.

title: BDS
text:
ADPC – Pharmacokinetics Concentrations

Based on SDTM PC (Pharmacokinetics Concentrations) domain

Measures drug levels in biofluids (e.g. plasma)

Used in non-compartmental PK analysis

title: BDS
text:
ADPPK – PK Parameters

Based on ADPC results

Derived AUC (Area Under Curve), Cmax (Maximum Concentration), Tmax (Time to Max Concentration), etc.

Used for dose-response modeling

title: BDS
text:
ADRS – Response Data

Derived from RS (Disease Response), TU (Tumor Identification), TR (Tumor Results) domains

Categorical outcomes: CR (Complete Response), PR (Partial Response), SD (Stable Disease), PD (Progressive Disease)

Often used in oncology

title: BDS
text:
ADTTE – Time to Event

Based on ADSL (Subject-Level) and AE (Adverse Events), DS (Disposition), VS (Vital Signs) events

Used for endpoints like OS (Overall Survival), PFS (Progression-Free Survival), time to death

Key variables: AVAL, CNSR (Censoring), STARTDT, ADT (Analysis Date)

title: BDS
text:
ADVS – Vital Signs

Based on SDTM VS (Vital Signs) domain

Derives BMI (Body Mass Index), MAP (Mean Arterial Pressure), etc.

Used in safety summaries

title: BDS
text:
Timing Variables
These variables place each observation in the study timeline and help track when it occurred relative to treatment, visits, or other study milestones.



Variable
Description
Why it’s Needed




ADT
Analysis date
Anchors timepoint in study


ADTM
Analysis datetime
Adds time granularity


ADY
Relative study day
For analysis over time

title: BDS
text:
Timing Variables
These variables place each observation in the study timeline and help track when it occurred relative to treatment, visits, or other study milestones.



Variable
Description
Why it’s Needed




ADTF, ATMF
Imputation flags
Tracks incomplete dates


AVISIT, AVISITN
Visit name/number
Sorting & summaries


APHASE, APERIOD
Study phase/period
For grouping data


ONTRTFL
On-treatment flag
Treatment window check

title: BDS
text:
Parameter Identification
These variables define what is being measured — each record in BDS must correspond to a unique parameter per subject per timepoint.



Variable
Description




PARAMCD
Short parameter code


PARAM
Full parameter name


PARAMN
Numeric ID (optional)


PARCAT1, PARCAT2
Parameter categories

title: BDS
text:
Result Variables
These variables store the main output of analysis — either numeric results or their character equivalents and categorized forms.



Variable
Description




AVAL
Numeric result


AVALC
Character result


AVALCATy
Categorization (e.g. low/normal/high)

title: BDS
text:
Derived Parameters
Used to compute secondary or composite measurements derived from primary variables, such as BMI or MAP.



Variable
Description




BMI, MAP, etc.
Derived from base measurements

title: BDS
text:
Reference Ranges
These help classify whether values are within normal clinical limits, often based on lab ranges.



Variable
Description




ANRLO, ANRHI
Normal limits


ANRIND
Low/High/Normal flag


BNRIND
Baseline version of ANRIND

title: BDS
text:
Baseline & Change
These variables allow comparison of on-treatment values to a defined pre-treatment baseline.



Variable
Description




BASE
Baseline value


CHG
Change from baseline


PCHG
Percent change


ABLFL
Baseline flag


BASETYPE
Type of baseline measurement

title: BDS
text:
Flags & Filtering
Binary flags are used to identify records relevant to specific analyses or TLGs.



Variable
Description




ANL01FL
Primary analysis record flag


ASEQ
Sequence number

title: BDS
text:
Treatment Assignment
Used to categorize subjects by planned and actual treatment arms.



Variable
Description




TRTA
Actual treatment


TRTP
Planned treatment

title: BDS
text:
Categorization & Criteria
Used to apply clinical cutoffs or create groupings based on results.



Variable
Description




AVALCATy
Categorized values


CRITy, CRITyFL, CRITyFN
Threshold logic (e.g., BP > 180)

title: BDS
text:
ADSL Merge & New Rows
Derived BDS datasets also pull in subject-level attributes from ADSL, and may create new rows summarizing or imputing data.

Add subject-level variables from ADSL (e.g. AGE, SEX, TRTSDT)
Derive new records (e.g. summary rows, worst value, average across visits)
